off_hours.window_control_profile.is_material_primary_lower_shift: True when negative primary pro-rate delta meets configured absolute floor.

artifacts.artifact_rows.artifact: Artifact/table identifier written by the pipeline.
artifacts.artifact_rows.rows: Number of rows available for that artifact/table in this run.

artifacts.artifact_rows.what_is_this: This table is a preview of artifacts artifact rows. It exposes row-level values behind chart aggregates so you can inspect the exact buckets, categories, and flags that produced a visual signal. Use it when you need to answer which concrete records created a peak, dip, or anomaly marker.
artifacts.artifact_rows.why_it_matters: Tables are essential for auditability: they let you sort, filter, and verify whether visual anomalies are supported by real volume, consistent metadata, and non-sparse support. They also reveal false positives where a chart looks dramatic but underlying rows are low-power or internally contradictory.
artifacts.artifact_rows.how_to_interpret: Start with key columns and filter around flagged times/categories. This table includes volume/count columns. Read left-to-right from identifiers to volume/rate fields to flags, and compare adjacent rows to separate isolated outliers from persistent structure. Use the column glossary to avoid over-interpreting similarly named fields with different semantics.
artifacts.artifact_rows.what_to_look_for: Look for rows where multiple indicators move together (for example, high counts plus directional rates plus flags), and check whether those rows cluster in adjacent windows. Strong evidence usually appears as recurring patterns across nearby rows, not single extreme entries.
artifacts.artifact_rows.momentary_high_low: A single extreme row can be a genuine event or a sparse-data outlier. Momentary lows can be normal lulls; validate by checking neighboring rows and low-power indicators. Short-lived highs often map to reminders, queue releases, or reporting timing; short-lived lows often map to expected inactivity or ingest lag.
artifacts.artifact_rows.extended_high_low: Extended runs of high/low values across many rows are stronger signs of regime-level behavior. Persistent shifts that also align with chart-level signals are higher-confidence anomalies. Extended highs may indicate sustained mobilization or process skew; extended lows may indicate suppressed activity, missing data segments, or a stable low-intensity baseline.
artifacts.artifact_rows.column_highlight: Primary columns in this preview: artifact, rows.

Use it when you need to answer which concrete records created a peak, dip, or anomaly marker.
off_hours.hourly_distribution.why_it_matters: Tables are essential for auditability: they let you sort, filter, and verify whether visual anomalies are supported by real volume, consistent metadata, and non-sparse support. They also reveal false positives where a chart looks dramatic but underlying rows are low-power or internally contradictory.
off_hours.hourly_distribution.how_to_interpret: Start with key columns and filter around flagged times/categories. This table includes rate/proportion columns, volume/count columns, time keys. Read left-to-right from identifiers to volume/rate fields to flags, and compare adjacent rows to separate isolated outliers from persistent structure. Use the column glossary to avoid over-interpreting similarly named fields with different semantics.
off_hours.hourly_distribution.what_to_look_for: Look for rows where multiple indicators move together (for example, high counts plus directional rates plus flags), and check whether those rows cluster in adjacent windows. Strong evidence usually appears as recurring patterns across nearby rows, not single extreme entries.
off_hours.hourly_distribution.momentary_high_low: A single extreme row can be a genuine event or a sparse-data outlier. Momentary lows can be normal lulls; validate by checking neighboring rows and low-power indicators. Short-lived highs often map to reminders, queue releases, or reporting timing; short-lived lows often map to expected inactivity or ingest lag.
off_hours.hourly_distribution.extended_high_low: Extended runs of high/low values across many rows are stronger signs of regime-level behavior. Persistent shifts that also align with chart-level signals are higher-confidence anomalies. Extended highs may indicate sustained mobilization or process skew; extended lows may indicate suppressed activity, missing data segments, or a stable low-intensity baseline.
off_hours.hourly_distribution.column_highlight: Primary columns in this preview: hour, n_total, n_pro, n_con, pro_rate, pro_rate_wilson_low.

analysis_catalog.title: Off-Hours Profile
analysis_catalog.how_to_read: Use the off-hours control timeline to compare observed pro share with Wilson uncertainty and primary expected/control bands (model-based when available, day-adjusted fallback otherwise) at each bucket size.
analysis_catalog.what_to_look_for: Sustained robust primary alerts (alert-eligible, below primary 99.8% lower control band, lower-tail FDR-supported, and materially negative) at adequate support, then verify whether the pattern repeats or clusters in specific dates/hours.
what_to_look_for_details: Prioritize robust primary alerts (below primary 99.8% lower limit, lower-tail FDR-significant, and materially negative delta at adequate support); avoid interpreting low-n windows even if raw rates look extreme.
If tested off-hours windows are zero after low-power filtering, treat the section as descriptive-only and avoid inferential conclusions.
Use the funnel view to compare primary and global expected bands; treat primary-baseline breaches as the decision metric and global bands as context.
In date-hour heatmaps, repeated overnight blocks across multiple dates are stronger than a single-night dip; corroborate with burst, periodicity, and duplicate detectors before escalation.
analysis_catalog.common_benign_causes: Time-zone spillover, campaign scheduling, and hearing-deadline pushes can produce legitimate overnight composition shifts.

help_sections.what_is_this: Off-Hours Profile focuses on model-aware off-hours composition shift with volume context. This section combines a hero chart, supporting charts, and tables to separate one-off noise from meaningful sustained behavior. Treat it as a detector notebook: start broad, then drill into specific windows with evidence context.
help_sections.why_it_matters: This data matters because it changes how confident you should be in an anomaly narrative. Strong claims should come from persistent, well-supported patterns rather than isolated spikes. It also prevents both over-calling benign fluctuations and missing slow-burn anomalies that only emerge over longer runs.
help_sections.how_to_interpret: Read the hero chart first for the dominant temporal structure, then use detail charts to test whether the signal repeats across scales, dayparts, or subgroup splits. Use tables to verify exact values and support counts behind flagged windows. When uncertainty bands or low-power markers are present, discount single-window jumps unless they recur with stronger support.
help_sections.what_to_look_for: Sustained robust primary alerts (alert-eligible, below primary 99.8% lower control band, lower-tail FDR-supported, and materially negative) at adequate support, then verify whether the pattern repeats or clusters in specific dates/hours. Prioritize robust primary alerts (below primary 99.8% lower limit, lower-tail FDR-significant, and materially negative delta at adequate support); avoid interpreting low-n windows even if raw rates look extreme. If tested off-hours windows are zero after low-power filtering, treat the section as descriptive-only and avoid inferential conclusions. Use the funnel view to compare primary and global expected bands; treat primary-baseline breaches as the decision metric and global bands as context. Investigation priority should increase when multiple independent views tell the same story at the same time.
help_sections.momentary_high_low: Momentary highs can indicate short overnight swings that stay within primary control limits after day/hour adjustment. Momentary lows can indicate small support windows where apparent extremes are likely sampling noise. Treat both cautiously when low-power flags are present. A practical rule: do not escalate on a single bucket unless a nearby table row and at least one companion chart support the same direction.
help_sections.extended_high_low: Extended highs can indicate repeating robust primary alerts across adjacent windows or nights at moderate/high support. Extended lows can indicate stable overnight behavior that remains inside expected primary control bands. Persistence across adjacent windows and corroborating detectors raises confidence that the shift is meaningful. Extended runs deserve timeline annotation and root-cause notes so later reviewers can separate operational context from suspicious behavior.

baseline_day_hour_volume.what_is_this: Day/hour baseline heatmap. This categorical/ranked chart compares values across labels, groups, or parameter settings. It emphasizes composition and concentration instead of chronology.
baseline_day_hour_volume.why_it_matters: Category comparisons show concentration, imbalance, and dominance patterns that can explain why timeline signals moved. They are often the fastest way to identify which subgroup is driving a detector outcome.
baseline_day_hour_volume.how_to_interpret: Sort by magnitude, compare head vs tail behavior, and relate category concentration to corresponding detector windows. Check both absolute values and relative spacing so you can distinguish true concentration from a uniformly low baseline.
baseline_day_hour_volume.what_to_look_for: Look for heavy concentration in a few categories, abrupt drop-offs, or rare categories with disproportionately high values. A long flat tail with one or two dominant bars often indicates a targeted driver worth validating in tables. Legend components: Cell color, X/Y axes.
baseline_day_hour_volume.momentary_high_low: A single dominant category may come from one campaign event or local data artifact. Check whether the dominance repeats over time. Momentary category suppression can also happen when total volume is temporarily low.
baseline_day_hour_volume.extended_high_low: Persistent dominance/absence across many categories can indicate structural participation effects rather than random variation. Extended concentration deserves follow-up to determine whether it is policy-driven outreach, operational process, or suspicious patterning.

bursts_hero_timeline.what_is_this: Observed burst counts with burst intensity overlay. This time-aligned view shows how the measured signal changes across chronological buckets. It is the primary lens for identifying sequence, duration, and coincidence with external events.
bursts_hero_timeline.why_it_matters: Time-series structure distinguishes transient spikes from sustained regime changes and helps align detector evidence by timestamp. Without duration context, it is easy to overreact to one-bucket noise and miss broad shifts.
bursts_hero_timeline.how_to_interpret: Read left to right, compare volume with rate/score overlays, and pay attention to uncertainty bounds and low-power markers where available. When zoomed in, verify whether local extremes persist across neighboring buckets and remain visible at wider scales.
bursts_hero_timeline.what_to_look_for: Look for repeated peaks, troughs, trend breaks, and persistent drifts across adjacent windows. Patterns that recur at the same daypart across dates are usually stronger than one isolated wave. Legend components: Observed count, Rate ratio.
bursts_hero_timeline.momentary_high_low: Short highs/lows can reflect event timing, random variance, or small-sample effects. Confirm with neighboring buckets before treating them as material anomalies. A momentary high near a known outreach time can be benign; a momentary low during expected peak periods may indicate data lag.
bursts_hero_timeline.extended_high_low: Extended highs/lows are stronger indicators of behavioral shifts, especially when they persist across multiple bucket sizes and coincide with corroborating detector outputs. Extended highs may indicate sustained mobilization or systematic bias; extended lows may indicate prolonged inactivity or missing segments.

duplicates_exact_top_names.what_to_look_for: Look for heavy concentration in a few categories, abrupt drop-offs, or rare categories with disproportionately high values. A long flat tail with one or two dominant bars often indicates a targeted driver worth validating in tables. Legend components: Bar height, X-axis.
duplicates_exact_top_names.momentary_high_low: A single dominant category may come from one campaign event or local data artifact. Check whether the dominance repeats over time. Momentary category suppression can also happen when total volume is temporarily low.
duplicates_exact_top_names.extended_high_low: Persistent dominance/absence across many categories can indicate structural participation effects rather than random variation. Extended concentration deserves follow-up to determine whether it is policy-driven outreach, operational process, or suspicious patterning.

duplicates_near_cluster_timeline.what_is_this: Near-duplicate cluster activity over time. This time-aligned view shows how the measured signal changes across chronological buckets. It is the primary lens for identifying sequence, duration, and coincidence with external events.
duplicates_near_cluster_timeline.why_it_matters: Time-series structure distinguishes transient spikes from sustained regime changes and helps align detector evidence by timestamp. Without duration context, it is easy to overreact to one-bucket noise and miss broad shifts.
duplicates_near_cluster_timeline.how_to_interpret: Read left to right, compare volume with rate/score overlays, and pay attention to uncertainty bounds and low-power markers where available. When zoomed in, verify whether local extremes persist across neighboring buckets and remain visible at wider scales.
duplicates_near_cluster_timeline.what_to_look_for: Look for repeated peaks, troughs, trend breaks, and persistent drifts across adjacent windows. Patterns that recur at the same daypart across dates are usually stronger than one isolated wave. Legend components: Cluster size, Records.
duplicates_near_cluster_timeline.momentary_high_low: Short highs/lows can reflect event timing, random variance, or small-sample effects. Confirm with neighboring buckets before treating them as material anomalies. A momentary high near a known outreach time can be benign; a momentary low during expected peak periods may indicate data lag.
duplicates_near_cluster_timeline.extended_high_low: Extended highs/lows are stronger indicators of behavioral shifts, especially when they persist across multiple bucket sizes and coincide with corroborating detector outputs. Extended highs may indicate sustained mobilization or systematic bias; extended lows may indicate prolonged inactivity or missing segments.

multivariate_feature_projection.what_is_this: Feature projection scatter. This scatter plot maps each bucket as a point in feature space, often with color and size as additional signals. It is a relationship view, showing joint behavior rather than a single metric over time.
multivariate_feature_projection.why_it_matters: Scatter views expose joint-feature structure, clusters, and outliers that are not visible in one-dimensional summaries. They help determine whether anomalies are isolated outliers or part of a broader feature-space regime.
multivariate_feature_projection.how_to_interpret: Read axis meaning first, then evaluate whether outliers are isolated or part of a cluster. Use color/size encodings to understand confidence and support. Cross-reference extreme points with time-based charts to determine whether they are single events or repeated states.
multivariate_feature_projection.what_to_look_for: Look for detached point clouds, extreme tails, and dense anomaly clusters that align with flagged windows. A compact cluster far from baseline often carries more weight than one far-away point with low support. Legend components: Point position, Point color, Point size.
multivariate_feature_projection.momentary_high_low: A single extreme point may be a one-off event or model artifact. Validate with timeline charts and table support counts. Momentary lows are usually returns toward baseline and are often benign unless paired with abrupt nearby outliers.
multivariate_feature_projection.extended_high_low: Large persistent outlier clusters imply broad feature-space drift. Extended low-intensity clustering implies stable baseline behavior. Sustained dual-cluster structure can indicate mixed populations or alternating operational modes.

off_hours_date_hour_primary_residual_hea.what_is_this: Date x hour heatmap for primary-baseline standardized residuals across the full 24-hour timeline. This is a matrix view where color encodes magnitude across paired axes such as date/hour or slot/day. Each cell is a compact summary of one intersection, so the chart is optimized for pattern shape over exact per-cell precision.
off_hours_date_hour_primary_residual_hea.why_it_matters: Heatmaps reveal spatially contiguous patterns that line charts can hide, especially repeated daypart behavior and slot-level drift. They are especially useful for finding regime-like blocks that persist across many adjacent cells.
off_hours_date_hour_primary_residual_hea.how_to_interpret: Scan for contiguous blocks before focusing on single cells. Compare high-intensity and low-intensity regions with bucket support and related detector outputs. Then check whether color transitions occur at meaningful boundaries such as day changes, hearing windows, or slot shifts.
off_hours_date_hour_primary_residual_hea.what_to_look_for: Look for coherent blocks, repeated stripes, or abrupt regime boundaries that persist across adjacent rows/columns. Short isolated hot/cold cells are weaker evidence; long bands or rectangles are stronger. Legend components: Cell color, Support, Off-hours emphasis, Axes.
off_hours_date_hour_primary_residual_hea.momentary_high_low: A single hot/cold cell can reflect transient activity or low support. Interpret isolated cells cautiously, especially if they do not repeat in neighboring slots. Momentary highs can map to one reminder wave; momentary lows can map to ordinary quiet periods.
off_hours_date_hour_primary_residual_hea.extended_high_low: Extended hot/cold regions typically indicate sustained behavioral mode shifts. Persistence across multiple dates/slots is stronger evidence than one transition point. Extended hot regions may indicate durable mobilization or process bias; extended cold regions may indicate suppression or inactivity.

procon_swings_day_hour_heatmap.what_is_this: Average pro-rate by weekday/hour. This is a matrix view where color encodes magnitude across paired axes such as date/hour or slot/day. procon_swings_day_hour_heatmap.why_it_matters: Heatmaps reveal spatially contiguous patterns that line charts can hide, especially repeated daypart behavior and slot-level drift. They are especially useful for finding regime-like blocks that persist across many adjacent cells.
procon_swings_day_hour_heatmap.how_to_interpret: Scan for contiguous blocks before focusing on single cells. Then check whether color transitions occur at meaningful boundaries such as day changes, hearing windows, or slot shifts.
procon_swings_day_hour_heatmap.what_to_look_for: Look for coherent blocks, repeated stripes, or abrupt regime boundaries that persist across adjacent rows/columns. Short isolated hot/cold cells are weaker evidence; long bands or rectangles are stronger. Legend components: Cell color, Axes.
procon_swings_day_hour_heatmap.momentary_high_low: A single hot/cold cell can reflect transient activity or low support. Interpret isolated cells cautiously, especially if they do not repeat in neighboring slots. Momentary highs can map to one reminder wave; momentary lows can map to ordinary quiet periods.
procon_swings_day_hour_heatmap.extended_high_low: Extended hot/cold regions typically indicate sustained behavioral mode shifts. Persistence across multiple dates/slots is stronger evidence than one transition point. Extended hot regions may indicate durable mobilization or process bias; extended cold regions may indicate suppression or inactivity.

voter_registry_match_rates.why_it_matters: Time-series structure distinguishes transient spikes from sustained regime changes and helps align detector evidence by timestamp. Without duration context, it is easy to overreact to one-bucket noise and miss broad shifts.
voter_registry_match_rates.how_to_interpret: Read left to right, compare volume with rate/score overlays, and pay attention to uncertainty bounds and low-power markers where available. When zoomed in, verify whether local extremes persist across neighboring buckets and remain visible at wider scales.
voter_registry_match_rates.what_to_look_for: Look for repeated peaks, troughs, trend breaks, and persistent drifts across adjacent windows. Patterns that recur at the same daypart across dates are usually stronger than one isolated wave. Legend components: Volume, Match rate, Wilson low / Wilson high, Exact match rate, Strong fuzzy match rate, Weak fuzzy match rate, Mean match confidence, Low-power.
voter_registry_match_rates.momentary_high_low: Short highs/lows can reflect event timing, random variance, or small-sample effects. Confirm with neighboring buckets before treating them as material anomalies. A momentary high near a known outreach time can be benign; a momentary low during expected peak periods may indicate data lag.
voter_registry_match_rates.extended_high_low: Extended highs/lows are stronger indicators of behavioral shifts, especially when they persist across multiple bucket sizes and coincide with corroborating detector outputs. Extended highs may indicate sustained mobilization or systematic bias; extended lows may indicate prolonged inactivity or missing segments.

voter_registry_match_tiers.what_is_this: Probabilistic voter-linkage tier composition. This categorical/ranked chart compares values across labels, groups, or parameter settings. It emphasizes composition and concentration instead of chronology.
voter_registry_match_tiers.why_it_matters: Category comparisons show concentration, imbalance, and dominance patterns that can explain why timeline signals moved. They are often the fastest way to identify which subgroup is driving a detector outcome.
voter_registry_match_tiers.how_to_interpret: Sort by magnitude, compare head vs tail behavior, and relate category concentration to corresponding detector windows. Check both absolute values and relative spacing so you can distinguish true concentration from a uniformly low baseline.
voter_registry_match_tiers.what_to_look_for: Look for heavy concentration in a few categories, abrupt drop-offs, or rare categories with disproportionately high values. A long flat tail with one or two dominant bars often indicates a targeted driver worth validating in tables. Legend components: Bar height, X-axis.
voter_registry_match_tiers.momentary_high_low: A single dominant category may come from one campaign event or local data artifact. Check whether the dominance repeats over time. Momentary category suppression can also happen when total volume is temporarily low.
voter_registry_match_tiers.extended_high_low: Persistent dominance/absence across many categories can indicate structural participation effects rather than random variation. Extended concentration deserves follow-up to determine whether it is policy-driven outreach, operational process, or suspicious patterning.

evidence_taxonomy.label: Calibrated empirical
evidence_taxonomy.description: Simulation/permutation calibrated evidence without closed-form p-values.

evidence_taxonomy.label: Heuristic
evidence_taxonomy.description: Structured indicator without formal significance control.

definitions.definition: Ranked candidate windows with score, support, caveats, and provenance fields used for investigator prioritization.
Signal provenance label (stat_fdr, calibrated_empirical, heuristic) that controls how strongly a result can be interpreted.
Buckets/windows with sparse support where rate metrics are unstable; low-power items are capped below high tier.
Binomial confidence interval for proportions; wider intervals indicate greater uncertainty from limited support.
False-discovery-rate adjusted p-value used to control multiple testing for hypothesis-tested detector families.
Triage score thresholds and support requirements that separate high, medium, and watch items.

tests_used.test_or_calibration: Poisson/empirical burst exceedance with FDR q-values
tests_used.notes: Prioritize contiguous elevated windows over isolated spikes.

tests_used.test_or_calibration: Proportion deltas with Wilson bounds and directional run summaries
tests_used.notes: Interpret sustained directional runs more strongly than single buckets.

tests_used.test_or_calibration: Clockface z-scores, autocorrelation, FFT peaks, rolling Fano
tests_used.notes: Require repeatability across adjacent lags/windows for escalation.

tests_used.test_or_calibration: Exact duplicate concentration and near-duplicate cluster timing
tests_used.notes: Combine with volume/timing context to reduce false positives.

tests_used.test_or_calibration: Tiered probabilistic matching with confidence summaries
tests_used.notes: Supporting context only; never standalone attribution.

multiple_testing_policy: Use q_value (FDR-adjusted) outputs for hypothesis-tested detector families.
Treat non-FDR heuristic/calibrated metrics as supporting evidence, not sole proof.
Escalate when multiple independent indicators align in the same time window.
caveats: Sparse windows can produce large but unstable rate swings.
Name/organization data quality issues can inflate duplicate or rarity signals.
Metadata-absent runs cannot support hearing-relative process interpretations.
Cross-hearing percentiles are corpus-relative and can shift as reports are added.
interpretation_guidance: Start with high-tier windows that have adequate support and non-low-power status.
Confirm each candidate with at least one independent detector family.
Prefer persistent multi-window patterns over one-bucket extremes.
Document plausible benign explanations before escalation.

ethical_guardrails.requirement: Describe findings as statistical irregularity requiring review, not proof of intent or misconduct.
Do not attribute coordination or identity claims from one detector or one artifact in isolation.
Treat probabilistic voter linkage as probabilistic supporting context only; never use it as standalone attribution.
